Manchester City will play against Arsenal in the English League Cup final at Wembley Stadium on March 22.The two teams currently sit first and second in the Premier League City reached the final after beating Newcastle 3-1 on Wednesday, completing a 5-1 win on aggregate in the semifinals.City had already led 2-0 from the first leg.Omar Marmoush scored two first-half goals, and Tijjani Reijnders added a third before halftime.“We’re here to win trophies and we give our best every day to reach these finals and win the silverware,” City forward Omar Marmoush - told Sky Sports.Newcastle scored once through substitute Anthony Elanga in the second half.Arsenal booked their place in the final with a 1-0 win over Chelsea on Tuesday, sealing a 4-2 aggregate victory.The final will be the first chance this season for either team to win a major trophy.Both clubs are still competing in the Premier League, Champions League, and FA Cup. Arsenal currently leads the league standings by six points ahead of City.The match continues a recent rivalry between the two clubs.City won the Premier League title in 2023 and 2024 after finishing ahead of Arsenal late in the season.Arsenal is aiming to win the league for the first time since 2004.The League Cup would be Mikel Arteta’s first major trophy since winning the FA Cup in 2020, his first season as Arsenal manager.Arteta previously worked as an assistant coach to Pep Guardiola at City.Guardiola is seeking his 16th major trophy since joining City in 2016 and his fifth League Cup.City has won the competition eight times, while Arsenal has won it twice, most recently in 1993.The final is a repeat of 2018, when Arteta was working under Guardiola and City won the competition.

Article Title: Dave Portnoy lashes out at Buccaneers over Tom Brady and Rob Gronkowski throwback ahead of Super Bowl LX
Article Text:
Dave Portnoy (Image via: IG/X)

Dave Portnoy questions Buccaneers’ timing as Patriots return to Super Bowl stage



With Super Bowl LX just hours away, the Tampa Bay Buccaneers found themselves pulled into the spotlight for reasons unrelated to this season. On Saturday, the team’s official social media account shared a throwback video featuring former stars Tom Brady and Rob Gronkowski celebrating their Super Bowl LV win. While the clip highlighted a proud moment in franchise history, the timing raised eyebrows, especially as attention across the league remains fixed on the New England Patriots and Seattle Seahawks preparing for Super Bowl LX.The post quickly drew a sharp reaction from Barstool Sports founder Dave Portnoy, who felt the Buccaneers were inserting themselves into a moment that did not belong to them. With New England back on the Super Bowl stage for the first time since the Brady era, Portnoy argued that the focus should remain on the teams competing on Sunday, not on memories from a past championship.Portnoy did not soften his criticism when responding to the post on social media. “It’s embarrassing. Never seen a franchise try to mooch off another franchise more than this,” he wrote, a comment that quickly gained traction among Patriots fans online. His reaction reflected a broader sentiment that Brady’s legacy is still closely tied to New England rather than Tampa Bay.Brady spent 20 seasons with the Patriots and won six Super Bowls during his time there, becoming the face of one of the most successful dynasties in NFL history.Although his move to Tampa Bay in 2020 led to immediate success, including a Super Bowl LV title, many fans still view his greatest achievements through the lens of his Patriots career. In that championship game against the Kansas City Chiefs, Brady threw for 201 yards and three touchdowns, two of them to Gronkowski, in a dominant 31-9 victory.Since Brady’s departure, the Patriots have endured a long championship drought. That storyline may finally be changing. Under new head coach Mike Vrabel, New England has rebuilt its identity and emerged as an unexpected Super Bowl contender. The team secured the AFC title with a gritty 10-7 win over the Denver Broncos and now faces Seattle in Super Bowl LX.As kickoff approaches, Portnoy’s comments underline a clear message. For Patriots supporters, this Super Bowl represents a chance to write a new chapter, one that stands on its own without being overshadowed by reminders from another franchise’s past.
Article Summary: The Tampa Bay Buccaneers shared a throwback video of Tom Brady and Rob Gronkowski celebrating their Super Bowl LV win. The post quickly drew a sharp reaction from Barstool Sports founder Dave Portnoy, who felt the Buccaneers were inserting themselves into a moment that did not belong to them. With New England back on the Super Bowl stage for the first time since the Brady era, PortNoy argued that the focus should remain on the teams competing on Sunday.

Article Title: Stefon Diggs drops an honest reality check after Patriots teammates mock his age
Article Text:
Stefon Diggs resoond to teammates age jokes(Image via: IG/X)

Stefon Diggs shares how locker room jokes about his age led to a simple reminder he once heard as a young player

Stefon Diggs did not lose his cool when the jokes started flying. Instead, he smiled and leaned into the moment. During Super Bowl LX week, the Patriots wideout admitted the younger guys in the room keep taking playful shots at his age. He answered with a calm reminder that hit deeper than the laughter.The timing makes it more interesting. New England is preparing for the biggest game of the season, yet the locker room still has space for banter. Diggs, now 32 and one of the oldest players on the roster, has turned those jokes into a small lesson about how fast an NFL career moves.Stefon Diggs spoke to reporters during the Super Bowl LX media conference in Santa Clara, where he opened up about the running joke inside the Patriots' wide receiver group. He kept the mood relaxed while explaining how often it comes up.“They make fun of me all the time,” Diggs said during the Super Bowl LX media session. The line did not come out of nowhere. Diggs said he once did the same thing earlier in his career. He recalled a moment with veteran receiver Mike Wallace that stayed with him over the years.“Mike Wallace told me a long time ago when I was young,” Diggs added.The popular wideout continued, “I think I met him in year seven or eight.I was like, 'Damn, you're old. 'And he'd say, 'You're going to be old one day too. 'I will never forget that statement. At this point, Pop [DeMario Douglas], Kyle Williams, and even Kayshon—they make fun of me all the time."To which popular WR responds, "Look, you’ll all be old one day too, and we’ll revisit this conversation again.”That memory now shapes how he handles jokes from younger teammates such as DeMario Douglas, Kyle Williams, and Kayshon Boutte. Instead of pushing back, he turns it into perspective. In his view, every young player reaches that point sooner than expected.The context around the moment matters. Diggs is in his first season with New England after signing a three-year, 69 million dollar deal last offseason. Despite the age talk, he still delivered on the field with his seventh 1,000-yard season, finishing with 1,013 yards as the Patriots pushed toward the Super Bowl.He also spoke about his growing chemistry with quarterback Drake Maye in that segment. “His maturation process is second to none,” Diggs said. “He’s still super young, but he plays at a high level. I’m a huge fan of him.”That mix of humor, memory, and production explains the moment. The jokes may be harmless, but Diggs answered with a veteran truth shaped by years in the league.
Article Summary: New England Patriots wideout Stefon Diggs is one of the oldest players on the roster. The 32-year-old says younger players make fun of him for his age all the time. Diggs said he once did the same thing earlier in his career. He recalled a moment with veteran receiver Mike Wallace that stayed with him.

Article Title: Is Travis Kelce really considering retirement? Insider reveals private conversations from tight end’s camp
Article Text:
Travis Kelce retirement rumors (Getty Images)

Travis Kelce’s retirement outlook remains fluid as Chiefs wait on his call



Travis Kelce's retirement talk refuses to cool down, but the facts right now point toward patience, not panic. The Kansas City Chiefs tight end remains undecided about his future, even as people close to him quietly lean toward another season. What matters most is simple. Kelce has not said he is done, and the Chiefs are prepared to welcome him back if he chooses to continue.That uncertainty defines this moment. After a rare losing season in Kansas City, questions around age, motivation, and legacy have followed Kelce into the offseason. Still, league insiders and team leadership see signs of unfinished business. For a player who has shaped an era at his position, the decision is bigger than one final year or one more run at a ring.Reports from The Athletic’s Dianna Russini suggest that retirement has been discussed, but not locked in. “I’m told that while retirement has been discussed, many close to Travis Kelce believe he could return for a 14th season,” Russini reported on Friday. “The future Hall of Famer has yet to make a final decision about his future.” That belief carries weight because it reflects conversations happening beyond microphones and press conferences.The Chiefs are clearly on board if Kelce wants to return for the 2026–2027 season. Team CEO Clark Hunt made that clear while balancing optimism with respect. “As an organization, we certainly hope that he will come back,” Hunt said. “He had another great year. Maybe not on par with where he was four or five years ago, but still had over 800 yards, was really one of the leaders on the offensive side of the ball for us. So there’s no doubt in my mind that he can still play. ”Kelce’s production backs that up. He finished the 2025 season with 76 receptions for 851 yards and two touchdowns on a team that struggled to find rhythm. Those numbers do not scream decline. They suggest adaptation. At 36, Kelce remains a reliable target and a locker room anchor, even as the Chiefs search for their next offensive identity.The long-term picture only strengthens his case. Kelce’s résumé already reads like a Hall of Fame blueprint. He owns 13,002 receiving yards, 1,080 receptions, and 82 receiving touchdowns, along with seven straight 1,000-yard seasons. Add 11 Pro Bowls, seven All-Pro selections, and three Super Bowl titles, and the question is no longer if he will reach Canton, but how quickly.Kelce himself is still weighing the personal cost. Tony Gonzalez, another gold-standard tight end, shared insight after spending time with him late in the season. “I did an interview with him on Christmas, sat down with him, spent some time with him after that on a personal level, and I really believe — he said it in the interview — he’s like, ‘I really don’t know.’ I believe him,” Gonzalez said. “Even in the interview, I was kind of like, ‘Come on, you know a little bit, you got to know something. ’”That honesty matters. Kelce also came up short at NFL Honors, leaving without the Walter Payton NFL Man of the Year Award after being nominated by the Chiefs. Bobby Wagner ultimately won, but the week reinforced Kelce’s standing as a respected figure on and off the field.For now, the noise around Travis Kelce retirement is louder than the answers. The Chiefs are waiting. The league is watching. And Kelce is taking his time, which may be the clearest signal that this story is not finished yet.
Article Summary: Travis Kelce's retirement talk refuses to cool down, but the facts right now point toward patience, not panic. The Kansas City Chiefs tight end remains undecided about his future, even as people close to him quietly lean toward another season. At 36, Kelce remains a reliable target and a locker room anchor.

Article Title: Shedeur Sanders’ 24th birthday takes an emotional turn as powerful viral message moves Deion Sanders
Article Text:
Deion Sanders and Shedeur Sanders (Image via: Andrew Wevers/Getty)

A fan message shifts focus on Shedeur Sanders’ first NFL season



Shedeur Sanders’ 24th birthday unfolded far differently from a typical celebration, marking a reflective moment in his young NFL journey. Now in his first year as a professional quarterback with the Cleveland Browns, Sanders reached a personal milestone shaped as much by scrutiny as by opportunity. His rookie season delivered moments of promise, but it also came with steady criticism that followed him from college into the league, fueled by expectations tied to his last name and draft-night storyline.Instead of a flood of birthday wishes, Sanders found himself at the center of a deeper online conversation. A long post shared on X by a user @Horvah76 quickly gained traction, standing out for its tone and intent. The message urged Sanders to stop carrying the weight of outside judgment and view his setbacks as part of a longer journey. As the post spread, it sparked discussion across NFL circles and soon drew attention well beyond the usual fan chatter.“Shedeur Sanders, I understand that today is your birthday, but this is not a 'Happy Birthday' post,” the user wrote. “This is a message.” The post challenged the narratives built around Sanders during the NFL draft process and questioned the faith placed in league decision-makers, including Browns head coach Kevin Stefanski.“God picked you….to have your character falsely attacked and assassinated by the national media in the months leading up to the draft,” the post continued. It also referenced Sanders falling out of the first round, framing the moment as public humiliation rather than a true measure of his talent. The message positioned those experiences as tests meant to shape Sanders’ character and future, rather than define his ceiling in the league.The emotional weight of the post caught the attention of Deion Sanders, who has remained closely connected to his son’s football path. The Colorado head coach reacted publicly, keeping his response short but meaningful. “This is Heavy! Lawd Jesus,” Sanders wrote, signaling how deeply the message resonated. For Shedeur Sanders, the viral moment underscored how closely his career continues to be watched.His rookie year included growth, learning, and criticism, much of it amplified by draft-night narratives and national attention. As he turns 24, the focus briefly shifted from results to resilience. With another season ahead, Sanders moves forward carrying lessons from a challenging first year.

Kardashian sisters curse and Super Bowl LX (Getty Images)

Rather than brushing off the chatter, Kim and Kylie are leaning in, placing real bets, and inviting millions of followers to watch the outcome unfold during one of the biggest nights in American sports.Kim Kardashian addressed the rumor directly while sharing her Fanatics Sportsbook slip ahead of the Feb. 8 Super Bowl matchup between the Seattle Seahawks and New England Patriots. “Here me out … I’m proving the curse ISN’T real because one of us will win,” she wrote on Instagram Stories Feb. 6. Her 69-cent wager on the Seahawks carries a potential payout of $347,222, a symbolic move that quickly went viral.Kylie Jenner followed with her own playful nod. “Kim traded on the Seahawks,” the 28-year-old posted on Instagram Stories Feb.8. “Am I saying I copied her by trading on the Seahawks?” The comment echoed Kim’s famous family joke about copying weddings, turning a betting choice into a pop culture callback.Meanwhile, Kendall Jenner took a different route. Seeking a more analytical angle, she consulted Tom Brady on The Tonight Show. “I am trying to figure out who I want to go for for the Super Bowl and I am an information person,” Kendall told Brady. “I feel like I need all the information I can get to make an educated decision. I was thinking you’re the perfect person to ask for that information.” After the call, she declared, “I feel I’m going to go Patriots. ”Kendall has also leaned into the myth through satire. In a new Fanatics Sportsbook ad, she jokes, “Haven’t you heard? Article Title: “That’s my man”: J Balvin fuels Super Bowl buzz backing Bad Bunny while rumors swirl about his secret guest appearance
Article Text:
J Balvin weighs in on Bad Bunny Super Bowl controversy (Getty Images)

J Balvin fires back at critics questioning Bad Bunny’s all-Spanish Super Bowl show



The Bad Bunny Super Bowl halftime show has become one of the most debated entertainment decisions in recent NFL history, and it will finally unfold on Sunday in Santa Clara. The league’s choice to hand the Super Bowl LX stage to the Puerto Rican superstar has stirred excitement, anger, and political noise in equal measure, weeks before a single note is played. Bad Bunny , born Benito Antonio Martínez Ocasio, will perform as the Seattle Seahawks face the New England Patriots, carrying the weight of cultural expectation along with the spotlight. Much of the backlash centers on language and politics, but close friend and global hitmaker J Balvin believes the controversy misses the point of music itself.J Balvin has been clear about why English-speaking audiences do not need translation to feel Bad Bunny’s performance. Speaking to TMZ, the Colombian singer framed the issue through his own experience as a young listener discovering hip-hop.“I learned and grew up listening to hip-hop,” Balvin said. “I didn’t know what they were saying. I would just vibe with it.”For Balvin, rhythm and emotion come before lyrics. “They just gotta jump on the flavor, that’s all they gotta do,” he added. “That’s followers.” His comments underline a broader idea the NFL appears to be embracing: the Super Bowl is no longer just an American event but a global one, shaped by sounds and cultures that travel beyond borders.The resistance, however, has been loud. President Donald Trump has been among the most vocal critics, while Hall of Fame running back Eric Dickerson questioned the NFL’s decision to look outside the local music scene. “Why can't we get somebody from right here, from home?” Dickerson asked. “I don't see why they chose that.” He also raised doubts about how a Spanish-language performance would land with a national audience.On being asked his favorite Bad Bunny song, Balvin said,"“All of them!” he said. That’s my man.”Bad Bunny has not softened his stance amid the criticism. He recently renewed his condemnation of ICE during his Grammy speech, continuing a pattern of speaking openly about issues that matter to him. The pressure has been intense. Days before the show, he admitted the buildup has been exhausting. “Thinking about the Super Bowl at 4am, that's what I've been doing,” he said. “Last night I couldn't sleep, I was thinking about it. ”Still, his focus remains on the moment itself. “I want to think it's 13 minutes of doing what I love,” Bad Bunny said. “I know I'm gonna have fun.”
Article Summary: J Balvin says Bad Bunny controversy misses the point of music. Colombian singer says English-speaking audiences do not need translation to feel Bad Bunny’s performance. Bad Bunny will perform as the Seattle Seahawks face the New England Patriots on Sunday in Santa Clara.
